articles.title: Government plans to overhaul asylum appeals system
articles.summary: The government would establish a new and independent body, with the aim of hearing cases more quickly.
articles.content:
Government plans to overhaul asylum appeals system

2 hours ago Share Save Iain Watson Political Correspondent, BBC News Tabby Wilson BBC News Share Save

PA Media Border Force officers processing the first small boat migrants detained under the UK's new "one in, one out" deal at the Manston Immigration Processing Centre in Manston, Kent, earlier this month

The government is planning an overhaul of the asylum appeals system, as it tries to cut the number of migrants staying in hotels while they await a ruling. A new, independent body will be established, staffed by independent adjudicators, with the aim of hearing cases more quickly. The Home Secretary, Yvette Cooper, said she was taking practical steps to end unacceptable delays. The government has been under increasing pressure to reduce its reliance on asylum hotels. It now wants to regain the initiative.

Ministers have pledged to end hotel use in this parliament - but 32,000 asylum seekers are still housed in them. Cooper said that while initial decisions on asylum applications had been speeded up, there had been "unacceptable delays" when people who were turned down decided to appeal. It currently takes on average just over a year for an appeal to be heard and 51,000 cases are awaiting a decision. During this time failed asylum seekers are accommodated at the taxpayers' expense. So a new panel of independent adjudicators is to be appointed to deal with appeals - ministers believe it will act more swiftly than the courts. The government has promised to give more details about how it will speed up cases in the autumn. The Conservatives have said the system is in chaos while Reform UK has argued for the mass deportation of those who arrive by illegal or irregular routes.

The past week has seen rising frustration over where asylum seekers are housed, with demonstrations held across the UK on Saturday to protest against the use of hotels. Epping has been a focal point for protesters since July, with thousands of people demonstrating outside the Bell Hotel after a resident asylum seeker was charged with sexually assaulting a 14-year-old girl in the town. On Tuesday the High Court granted the council a temporary injunction to block asylum seekers from being housed in the Bell Hotel, after it argued that the hotel had breached local planning controls by changing its use, resulting in events that were a public safety risk. Those currently in residence must be moved out by 16:00 on 12 September. The government is seeking the right to appeal against the High Court ruling. Cooper said the government was committed to closing all asylum hotels but that it needed to happen in "a properly managed way".
articles.reasoning: The government is taking concrete steps to improve the asylum appeals system by establishing an independent body to speed up case hearings, which addresses unacceptable delays and aims to reduce the time asylum seekers spend in temporary hotel accommodations. This has broad societal significance as it impacts thousands of asylum seekers and taxpayers, and represents a meaningful policy change with potential to improve the fairness and efficiency of the asylum process.
articles.personality_title: Government to create independent body to speed up asylum appeals
articles.personality_presentation:
**Context** – The UK government has faced criticism for long delays in handling asylum appeals. Many asylum seekers wait in hotels for decisions, which has caused concern among communities and officials.

**What happened** – The government announced plans to set up a new, independent group of adjudicators to hear asylum appeals faster. This body will replace the current system, where appeals can take over a year. The Home Secretary, Yvette Cooper, said this change aims to reduce delays and help move people out of temporary hotel housing quicker.

**Impact** – This new system is important because it could shorten waiting times for thousands of asylum seekers. Right now, 51,000 appeals are pending, and many people live in hotels paid for by taxpayers. Faster decisions mean less time in hotels and lower costs. It also responds to public concerns about safety and local community pressures.

**What's next step** – The government plans to share more details about how the new appeals body will work in the autumn. Meanwhile, it will try to close all asylum hotels carefully and legally, especially after recent court rulings affecting some locations.

**One-sentence takeaway** – The UK government is creating an independent appeals panel to speed up asylum decisions and reduce the time people spend in temporary hotel housing.
articles.personality_title_fr: Le gouvernement crée un organe indépendant pour accélérer les appels d'asile
articles.personality_presentation_fr:
**Contexte** – Le gouvernement britannique a été critiqué pour les longs délais dans le traitement des appels d'asile. Beaucoup de demandeurs d'asile attendent dans des hôtels, ce qui a suscité des inquiétudes dans les communautés et chez les autorités.

**Ce qui s'est passé** – Le gouvernement a annoncé la création d'un nouveau groupe indépendant d'arbitres pour examiner plus rapidement les appels d'asile. Ce corps remplacera le système actuel, où les appels peuvent durer plus d'un an. La ministre de l'Intérieur, Yvette Cooper, a déclaré que ce changement vise à réduire les délais et à faire sortir plus vite les personnes des hôtels temporaires.

**Impact** – Ce nouveau système est important car il pourrait raccourcir les temps d'attente pour des milliers de demandeurs d'asile. Actuellement, 51 000 appels sont en attente, et beaucoup vivent dans des hôtels payés par les contribuables. Des décisions plus rapides signifient moins de temps passé dans les hôtels et des coûts moindres. Cela répond aussi aux préoccupations publiques sur la sécurité et les pressions locales.

**Prochaines étapes** – Le gouvernement prévoit de donner plus de détails sur le fonctionnement du nouveau corps d'appel à l'automne. En attendant, il tentera de fermer tous les hôtels d'asile de manière prudente et légale, surtout après des décisions de justice récentes concernant certains lieux.

**Résumé en une phrase** – Le gouvernement britannique crée un panel d'appel indépendant pour accélérer les décisions d'asile et réduire le temps passé dans les hôtels temporaires.
articles.personality_title_es: El gobierno creará un órgano independiente para acelerar las apelaciones de asilo
articles.personality_presentation_es:
**Contexto** – El gobierno del Reino Unido ha sido criticado por las largas demoras en el manejo de las apelaciones de asilo. Muchos solicitantes esperan en hoteles mientras se toman decisiones, lo que ha generado preocupación en las comunidades y autoridades.

**Qué pasó** – El gobierno anunció planes para crear un nuevo grupo independiente de adjudicadores que escuchen las apelaciones de asilo más rápido. Este organismo reemplazará el sistema actual, donde las apelaciones pueden tardar más de un año. La ministra del Interior, Yvette Cooper, dijo que este cambio busca reducir las demoras y ayudar a que las personas salgan más rápido de los alojamientos temporales en hoteles.

**Impacto** – Este nuevo sistema es importante porque podría acortar los tiempos de espera para miles de solicitantes de asilo. Actualmente, hay 51,000 apelaciones pendientes y muchas personas viven en hoteles pagados por los contribuyentes. Decisiones más rápidas significan menos tiempo en hoteles y menores costos. También responde a preocupaciones públicas sobre la seguridad y la presión de las comunidades locales.

**Próximo paso** – El gobierno planea compartir más detalles sobre cómo funcionará el nuevo órgano de apelaciones en otoño. Mientras tanto, intentará cerrar todos los hoteles para solicitantes de asilo de forma cuidadosa y legal, especialmente después de recientes fallos judiciales.

**Resumen en una frase** – El gobierno del Reino Unido está creando un panel independiente para acelerar las decisiones de asilo y reducir el tiempo que las personas pasan en hoteles temporales.
